newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Huge state-owned firms chief Yugo loss-makers. [CORRECTED 20:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Huge state-owned firms chief Yugo loss-makers. [CORRECTED 20:00 GMT]

text.p: Yugoslav companies suffered 8.75 billion dinars ($1.54 billion) in aggregate net losses in 1996, Belgrade-based Institute for Economic Sciences (IEN) said on Wednesday.
According to IEN's analysis, based on 1996 annual balance sheets, net loss was 2.5 billion dinars lower than in 1995.

IEN economist Jovan Rankovic (corrects to give source's identity) said large state-owned firms were chiefly to blame for a catastrophic situation in the Yugoslav economy reflected in general insolvency.
Out of 72,721 active enterprises, 4,744 are state-owned and are the biggest loss-makers, incurring a net loss of some 6.6 billion dinars ($1.17 billion).
"If they were eliminated the rest of the economy would be solvent," Rankovic said.
Some 1,049 large firms, with 932,000 workers or some 55 percent of the total number of employed, accounted for 7.355 billion dinars in net losses in 1996.
Rankovic said the situation was the worst for 543 public utility companies which generated 45 percent of net loss in 1996.
According to IEN, ten enterprises employing only 45,554 people are the biggest loss makers.
"Eight of them are in the power sector, one is the only oil and gas producer and one is from chemical industry sector," Rankovic said.

"Large socially-owned firms, relics of the old state-controlled economy, are a millstone around our neck pulling us down into an economic abyss," he said. -- Gordana Kukic, Belgrade Newsroom +38 111 222 4254
